case.name: Rutter v Brookland Valley Estate Pty Limited [2009] FCA 702 (30 June 2009)

citphrases.citphrase: assessment of damages on the basis of a royalty inappropriate
whether loss of sales by the copyright owner could be inferred merely from the fact of sales of infringing product
requirement for evidence of lost sales and value of such sales
data access corporation v powerflex services pty ltd intellectual property
words used as commands in one computer language used as commands with identical functions in another computer language
whether copyright subsists in an individual command
whether an individual command is itself a "computer program" within s 10(1) of the copyright act 1968 (cth). infringement of copyright
application development system designed to enable computer programs to be written using certain commands
whether a collocation of those commands constitutes a "substantial part" of the application development system
test of substantiality as applied to computer programs. infringement of copyright
whether a macro in one computer program is an "adaptation" of a macro with the same functionality in another computer program
meaning of "version" in s 10(1) of the copyright act 1968 (cth). subsistence of copyright
computer data table used for standard data compressions
whether the data table is an "original literary work". infringement of copyright
whether process devised to replicate a computer data table by examining its output constitutes a "reproduction" of the table.
power to vacate before order passed and entered
calculation of damages under s.115(2) and (4) copyright act.
alleged infringement of copyright of project home house plans
general principles regarding damages or account of profits
cost of the proceedings a factor in the award of exemplary damages. practice & procedure
application to set aside default judgment

citances.sentence: In coming to my conclusion as to the quantum of additional damages I was reminded by the applicant that in APRA v Cougars Tavern & Ors [2008] FMCA 369 I took into account the views expressed in a number of past cases. [8] He then helpfully referred to some cases not mentioned there and others of a more recent vintage. [9] The respondent submitted that the pecuniary damages in TS & B Retail (supra) were calculated by reference to a sample and suggested that the amount of additional damages took into account the possibility that the pecuniary damages did not really reflect the extent of the infringement whereas in the instant case the exact extent of the infringement was known by virtue of the evidence of Ms Tang. The respondent noted that the Elwood Clothing Pty Ltd v Cotton On Clothing Pty Ltd [2009] FCA 633 ; (2009) 81 IPR 378 case was a counterfeiting operation and that in Rutter v Brooklyn Valley Estate Pty Ltd [2009] FCA 702 ; (2009) 81 IPR 549 there was a long-term series of infringement from 1999 onwards until judgment. The Aristocrat Technologies Australia Pty Ltd v Global Gaming Supplies Pty Ltd [2009] FCA 1495 ; (2009) 84 IPR 222 decision was also one involving a long-term full scale counterfeiting operation. In coming to my conclusion as to the quantum of additional damages I was reminded by the applicant that in APRA v Cougars Tavern & Ors [2008] FMCA 369 I took into account the views expressed in a number of past cases. [8] He then helpfully referred to some cases not mentioned there and others of a more recent vintage. [9] The respondent submitted that the pecuniary damages in TS & B Retail (supra) were calculated by reference to a sample and suggested that the amount of additional damages took into account the possibility that the pecuniary damages did not really reflect the extent of the infringement whereas in the instant case the exact extent of the infringement was known by virtue of the evidence of Ms Tang. The respondent noted that the Elwood Clothing Pty Ltd v Cotton On Clothing Pty Ltd [2009] FCA 633 ; (2009) 81 IPR 378 case was a counterfeiting operation and that in Rutter v Brooklyn Valley Estate Pty Ltd [2009] FCA 702 ; (2009) 81 IPR 549 there was a long-term series of infringement from 1999 onwards until judgment. The Aristocrat Technologies Australia Pty Ltd v Global Gaming Supplies Pty Ltd [2009] FCA 1495 ; (2009) 84 IPR 222 decision was also one involving a long-term full scale counterfeiting operation.

There is significant authority in relation to the application of this section and the considerations relevant to an award of exemplary damages. The following cases are but a sample: Raben Footwear v Polygram Records Inc , [164] Woolworths Ltd v Olson , [165] Norm Engineering v Digga Australia , [166] Aristocrat Technologies Australia Pty Ltd v DAP Services (Kempsey) Pty Ltd (in Liq) , [167] Luxottica Retail Australia Pty Ltd v Grant , [168] Rutter v Brookland Valley Estate Pty Ltd , [169] and Deckers Outdoor Corporation Inc v Farley . [170]

legistitles.title: COPYRIGHT ACT 1968
COPYRIGHT ACT 1968 - SECT 14 Acts done in relation to substantial part of work or other subject-matter deemed to be done in relation to the whole
COPYRIGHT ACT 1968 - SECT 31 Nature of copyright in original works
COPYRIGHT ACT 1968 - SECT 35 Ownership of copyright in original works
COPYRIGHT ACT 1968 - SECT 36 Infringement by doing acts comprised in the copyright
COPYRIGHT ACT 1968 - SECT 115 Actions for infringement
COPYRIGHT ACT 1968 - SECT 134 Limitation of actions in respect of infringement of copyright
COPYRIGHT ACT 1968 - SECT 195AO Infringement of right of attribution of authorship
COPYRIGHT ACT 1968 - SECT 195AZA Remedies for infringements of author's moral rights
FEDERAL COURT OF AUSTRALIA ACT 1976
FEDERAL COURT OF AUSTRALIA ACT 1976 - SECT 51A Interest up to judgment
FEDERAL COURT RULES
